Class ChangeMaking

  • java.lang.Object
    • ChangeMaking

  • public class ChangeMaking
extends java.lang.Object
    Classical Change making problem with an unlimited amount of coins of each type.
    Version 2: Selection function with more elaborated policy: First biggest-coin.
    Depending on the type of coins, it can lead to an optimal solution.
    The class encapsulates all the functions of the Greedy schema

      Constructors

      ChangeMaking()
      Constructor of the class.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean feasibilityTest(int candidateValue, int amount, int changeGenerated)
      Given a current solution and a selected candidate, this function states whether the candidate must be added to the solution or discarded.
      int objectiveFunction(MyList<java.lang.Integer> sol)
      Given the final solution to the problem, this function computes its objective function value according to:
      How many coins are used in the solution.
      int selectionFunctionBestCandidate(MyList<java.lang.Integer> candidates)
      Given a current solution that is not a final solution, this function selects the new candidate to be added to it.
      The policy followed is more elaborated: Pick the best coin according to the objective function of minimizing the number of coins that make the change of the amount.
      int selectionFunctionFirstCandidate(MyList<java.lang.Integer> candidates)
      Given a current solution that is not a final solution, this function selects the new candidate to be added to it.
      The policy followed is very simple: Just pick the first unused item.
      boolean solutionTest(MyList<java.lang.Integer> candidates)
      Given a current solution, this function states whether it is a final solution or it can still be improved.
      To determine it, it checks whether there is (at least) one item not picked before that fits into the knapsack.
      MyList<java.lang.Integer> solve(int typeSelectFunc, MyList<java.lang.Integer> coinValues, int amount)
      Given an instance of the GP1 problem, this function solves it using a greedy algorithm.

    • Method Detail

      • selectionFunctionFirstCandidate

        public int selectionFunctionFirstCandidate(MyList<java.lang.Integer> candidates)
        Given a current solution that is not a final solution, this function selects the new candidate to be added to it.
        The policy followed is very simple: Just pick the first unused item.
        Parameters:
        candidates: - The MyList stating whether a candidate has been selected so far or not.

      • selectionFunctionBestCandidate

        public int selectionFunctionBestCandidate(MyList<java.lang.Integer> candidates)
        Given a current solution that is not a final solution, this function selects the new candidate to be added to it.
        The policy followed is more elaborated: Pick the best coin according to the objective function of minimizing the number of coins that make the change of the amount.
        Parameters:
        candidates: - List of candidates

      • feasibilityTest

        public boolean feasibilityTest(int candidateValue,
                               int amount,
                               int changeGenerated)
        Given a current solution and a selected candidate, this function states whether the candidate must be added to the solution or discarded.
        Parameters:
        candidateValue: - The value of the candidate coin selected.
        amount: - The amount of change we want to generate.
        changeGenerated: - The quantity of change we have generated so far.

      • solutionTest

        public boolean solutionTest(MyList<java.lang.Integer> candidates)
        Given a current solution, this function states whether it is a final solution or it can still be improved.
        To determine it, it checks whether there is (at least) one item not picked before that fits into the knapsack.
        Parameters:
        candidates: - candidates coins

      • objectiveFunction

        public int objectiveFunction(MyList<java.lang.Integer> sol)
        Given the final solution to the problem, this function computes its objective function value according to:
        How many coins are used in the solution.
        Parameters:
        sol: - The MyList containing the solution to the problem.

      • solve

        public MyList<java.lang.Integer> solve(int typeSelectFunc,
                                       MyList<java.lang.Integer> coinValues,
                                       int amount)
        Given an instance of the GP1 problem, this function solves it using a greedy algorithm.
        Parameters:
        typeSelectFunc: - Type of selection function to choose.
        coinValues: - A MyList containing the value of each type of coin supported.
        amount: - The amount of change we want to generate.
